CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider drains fluid from an abscess, cyst, or hematoma, from the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This procedure involves a simple drainage.

Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an incision in the posterior one third of the tongue and excises the affected tissues for the purpose of biopsy.
CPT.explanation: 41105 pertains to biopsy of oral mucosa and/or lesion; vestibule of mouth.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider excises a lesion from the posterior one thirds of the tongue.
CPT.explanation: 41113 pertains to excision of lesion of floor of mouth.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider removes a foreign body present in the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This procedure involves a simple removal.
CPT.explanation: 40804 pertains to excision of lesion, vestibule of mouth (mucocele).

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider open (incises) and drains the contents of a pilonidal cyst.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 10080 – Incision & Drainage (I&D) of a SIMPLE PILONIDAL CYST  
Mnemonic: “80 SITS on the TAIL-BONE—NOWHERE ELSE”

─────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. ONE-LINE DEFINITION  
Single scalpel incision in the natal cleft (sacrococcygeal “tail-bone” area) to release an abscess limited to the primary pilonidal pocket, followed by minimal irrigation / light packing—nothing more.

2. CODE-IT CHECKLIST (EVERY BOX MUST BE ✓)  
☐ Anatomic site = mid-line intergluteal / sacrococcygeal area (true pilonidal)  
☐ Action words = “incision & drainage,” “stab incision,” “simple I&D”  
☐ Complexity = ONE opening, no branching tracts, no wide excision  
☐ Devices left behind = NONE (loose wick or light gauze is OK)  
☐ No additional work = no curettage, no seton, no drain, no flap, no marsupialization  

If any box is ✗, do NOT bill 10080.

3. FAST DECISION TREE (EXAM & REAL WORLD)  
A. Where is the abscess?  
   • Natal cleft / tail-bone → go to B.  
   • Anywhere else (thigh, axilla, breast, groin, face, etc.) → use General Abscess Pathway (10060/10061/10160/10180).  

B. Pilonidal location—what was done?  
   • One incision, simple drainage → 10080  
   • Multiple incisions, curettage, seton/drain, deroofing → 10081 (complicated)  
   • Formal excision of cyst/sinus tracts → 11770–11772 (excision series)

4. “RED-LIGHT” SITUATIONS—10080 IS WRONG IF:  
✗ Site is NOT natal cleft (even if the note says “pilonidal-type abscess”).  
✗ Only a needle or catheter used → 10160 (needle aspiration) or 10021 (FNA)  
✗ Post-operative wound abscess → 10180  
✗ Entire cyst/tracts excised → 11770–11772  
✗ Penrose, suction drain, or seton left in place → 10081

5. MOST COMMON MIX-UP: 10060 vs 10080  
10060 = Simple I&D of abscess ANYWHERE on the body EXCEPT the natal cleft.  
10080 = Simple I&D ONLY in the natal cleft.  
Quick memory hook: “60 can go anywhere; 80 sits on the tail-bone.”

6. MINI-SCRIPTS—WHAT TO CODE  
✓ 10080 (CORRECT)  
“1-cm midline incision within natal cleft; purulent fluid drained, cavity irrigated, iodoform wick placed. No secondary tracts.”  
✗ 10060 (NOT 10080) – Thigh example  
“1.5-cm fluctuant abscess on anterior thigh; single stab incision, pus evacuated, gauze packing inserted.”  
✗ 10160 (NOT 10080) – Needle only  
“18-g needle aspiration of axillary abscess; no scalpel incision performed.”  
✗ 11770 (NOT 10080) – Excision  
“Elliptical excision of pilonidal cyst with all sinus tracts down to fascia; wound closed primarily.”

7. RAPID “YES/NO” STICKER FOR YOUR MONITOR  
Tail-bone? YES  
Scalpel cut? YES  
Simple drain/pack only? YES  
→ 10080  
If any answer is NO → pick 10060, 10061, 10081, 10160, 10180, or 11770-11772 as appropriate.

8. REAL-WORLD TIP  
Operative notes that say only “I&D abscess” are dangerous. Before you default to 10060/10061, scan for the words “intergluteal,” “natal cleft,” or “sacrococcygeal.” If absent, assume NOT pilonidal.

BOTTOM LINE  
10080 = Tail-bone + ONE scalpel incision + SIMPLE drainage.  
Anything else? Different code.

CPT.description: Fine Needle Aspiration Biopsy Procedures Summary: The provider performs a fine needle aspiration (FNA), a diagnostic procedure that involves collecting a small number of cells, a small amount of tissue, or fluid from a cyst or mass using a specialized needle and syringe. Report this code for the first lesion biopsied.

Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider incises the area of abscess and drains the collection of pus from a lesion, such as a carbuncle, hidradenitis, cyst, furuncle, or paronychia, with the help of surgical instruments. A simple incision and drainage usually involves a single incision of an abscess situated just below the skin's surface.
CPT.explanation: 10060 is the CPT code for incision and drainage of abscess (e.g., carbuncle, suppurative hidradenitis, cutaneous or subcutaneous abscess, cyst, furuncle, or paronychia); simple or single.

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider inserts a needle into a fluid deposit area on the skin and aspirates fluid or pus to obtain a culture.

CPT.explanation:
══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
CPT 20005 – Incision & Drainage, Superficial Abscess / Hematoma / Seroma /
                 Inflamed Bursa   ANATOMIC ZONE: LOWER-LEG & ANKLE ONLY
                 (knee-joint line → but NOT including the foot)
══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

1. THREE “LOCK-IN” QUESTIONS – all must be YES or code out:
   A. Where is the lesion?   Below the patella AND above the malleoli (calf, shin, Achilles area, medial / lateral malleolus)      YES / NO  
   B. How deep is it?        ONLY superficial / subcutaneous / bursal. No mention of fascia, muscle, deep compartments, or a drain left in place.      YES / NO  
   C. What was done?         Simple I&D (incise, break loculations, irrigate, pack or loosely close). No counter-incisions, no complex closure.      YES / NO  

   If ANY answer = NO → 20005 is wrong. Go to 20002 (thigh/knee), 20006 (deep lower-leg), or 10060/10061 (other body areas) as appropriate.

2. THE #1 CONFUSION PAIR – 20005 vs. 20010  
   • 20005 = DISTAL, lower-leg/ankle surface drain   (“I’m working near the cleats.”)  
   • 20010 = PROXIMAL, upper-arm/elbow surface drain (“I can shake the patient’s hand.”)  
   Mnemonic: ODD numbers march DISTAL (…-05 = lower leg) – EVEN numbers march PROXIMAL (…-10 = upper arm).

   Football-collision hematoma, UPPER ARM → 20010, never 20005. Highlight this in audits; it is the most frequent mis-pick.

3. COMMON TRAPS & SAFETY FLAGS
   • Op note says “drain left in situ” or “deep lateral compartment opened” → automatically 20006 (deep).  
   • Ankle, heel cord, malleolus abscess mistakenly sent out on 10060/10061 → change to 20005 (musculoskeletal section wins over integumentary).  
   • “Just under the skin of the knee” but you can palpate patella → too high → 20002, not 20005.  
   • Documentation uses vague term “leg” only: Force the surgeon to state CALF / SHIN / ANKLE or you cannot defend 20005.

4. DOCUMENTATION CHECKLIST – have ALL THREE:
   ☐ Exact distal-leg word (calf, shin, Achilles, ankle, medial/lateral malleolus)  
   ☐ Depth descriptor (superficial, subcutaneous, seroma cavity, bursal)  
   ☐ Simple I&D steps only, no drain left  

   Miss one box? Query or recode.

5. REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES
   ✓ “3-cm purulent seroma, right calf; 1-cm incision, blunt dissection, irrigation, iodoform packing.” → CPT 20005  
   ✓ “Posterior ankle (Achilles) bursitis with abscess; superficial I&D performed, no drain.” → 20005  
   ✗ “Hematoma, upper arm from football tackle; 2-cm incision, evacuated.” → 20010 (NOT 20005)  
   ✗ “Deep intramuscular calf abscess; counter-incision, Penrose drain left.” → 20006  

6. GLOBAL INFORMATION
   • 10-day global period.  
   • Bundles incision, drainage, manual breakup of loculations, irrigation, simple closure/packing.

ONE-LINE TAKEAWAY  
20005 lives strictly between the knee joint line and the malleoli and stays superficial—think “simple surface drain on the shin/ankle.” Anything higher, lower, or deeper—STOP—pick a different code.

================================================================================
CPT 20010 ‑ Incision & Drainage (I&D) of Hematoma, Seroma, Traumatic or Post-Operative Fluid Collection  
ANATOMIC ZONE: UPPER ARM or ELBOW — OPEN, DEEP
================================================================================

A. WHAT 20010 ACTUALLY PAYS FOR
• A brand-new, surgical-suite incision that passes through ALL three layers  
  – Skin → Sub-cutaneous fat → Investing fascia  
  – Enters an intramuscular, inter-muscular, or sub-fascial space.  
• Complete evacuation / lysis of loculations, copious irrigation, optional limited debridement, and placement of a drain or packing.  
• Simple skin closure, if performed.

B. THE TWO NON-NEGOTIABLE FENCEPOSTS  
   1. PROXIMAL limit: just distal to the glenohumeral (shoulder) joint  
   2. DISTAL limit: tip of the olecranon (elbow)  

If the operative note mentions ANY other anatomic region—shoulder, axilla, forearm, thigh, knee, hip, leg, chest wall, back, etc.—20010 is automatically wrong.

C. 3-STEP “QUICK CHECK” BEFORE YOU CODE  
1. Site                       → Is it clearly “upper arm” or “elbow”?  
2. Depth                      → Was the fascia opened OR does the note state intra-/inter-muscular, sub-fascial, or deep space?  
3. New Incision vs. Re-open   → Was a NEW cut made (or is there modifier 58/78/79 justification)?  

YES to all three = 20010.  
If any answer is NO, look elsewhere (see Section E).

D. MINIMUM DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT 20010  
1. Laterality + exact site (“left distal upper arm,” “right posterior elbow”)  
2. Statement of fascial entry / deep cavity (“fascia incised; cavity noted in intramuscular plane”)  
3. Type + estimated volume of fluid evacuated  
4. Details of irrigation, debridement, drain or packing  
5. Confirmation this was a NEW incision (or modifier explanation)

E. CODES MOST FREQUENTLY CONFUSED WITH 20010 — HOW TO TELL THEM APART

• 27301  (Thigh / knee, deep): If the note says “thigh,” “quadriceps,” or “hamstring,” STOP — thigh has its own dedicated deep I&D code (27301). 20010 is never correct for thigh seromas or abscesses.  
• 25028  (Forearm / wrist, deep): Same concept for distal arm.  
• 27030  (Hip), 27603 (Leg), 20016 (Trunk, when no regional code exists) — Use the region-specific deep I&D code whenever it exists; default to 20016 only when NONE exists (e.g., chest wall, back).  
• 10140  / 10160  (Superficial hematoma/seroma OR abscess): Use when tissue plane is limited to skin/sub-Q. These are “lump-in-office” procedures, not OR deep dissections.  
• 20005  / 20055: These are highly specialized codes (e.g., ring removal, halo traction, etc.) and almost never correct for a routine extremity fluid collection. When you see a simple seroma or hematoma, mentally cross -out 20005 and 20055 unless the op note describes the very specific scenario printed in CPT.

F. EXAM & REAL-WORLD “GOTCHAS”  
• Thigh ≠ Arm: On tests, “seroma in the thigh” almost always maps to 27301—not 20010, 20005, or 20055.  
• “Near the elbow” ≠ “Elbow”: Make sure the dictation states the incision was within the fenceposts and not on the proximal forearm.  
• “Re-opening of recent incision” during the global period is bundled (modifier 78); do not assign 20010 unless modifier criteria are met.

G. MEMORY HOOK  
“Two joints guard 20010: shoulder above, elbow below. If you read anything outside those guards—drop the code and go to the region-specific option.”

================================================================================

CPT 20020  
Incision and Removal of Foreign Body, Subcutaneous Tissue – SIMPLE

----------------------------------------------------
1. PLAIN-ENGLISH DEFINITION (“Stab-and-Grab”)
A tiny skin nick (≤1 cm) made only deep enough to enter the subcutaneous fat, followed by extraction of an inert, NON-living item (splinter, glass, gravel, metal, bullet fragment, plastic, etc.). Closure, if any, is a single simple suture; no undermining, no layered repair, no drain.

----------------------------------------------------
2. THE “S-O-S” RULE—EVERY LETTER MUST BE IN THE NOTE
S  Subcutaneous ONLY – the surgeon never crosses fascia or touches muscle, tendon, joint, or bone.  
O  Object is NON-LIVING – foreign body = not biologic: wood, glass, metal, plastic, stone.  
S  Simple Technique – ≤1 cm skin incision, no enlargement, no debridement, no drain, no layered closure.

Miss any letter → abandon 20020.

----------------------------------------------------
3. HARD-STOP WORDS—AUTOMATIC “NOT 20020”
cyst ganglion lipoma neuroma nodule tumor mass abscess hematoma seroma implant hardware  
These describe biologic tissue or fluid collections. Use lesion-excision or I&D codes instead.

----------------------------------------------------
4. RAPID DIFFERENTIAL—WHAT CODE WHEN?
WHAT CAME OUT? WHERE WAS IT? HOW DEEP WAS CUT? CODE
• Inert object   Subcutaneous  ≤1 cm nick    → 20020
• Pus/blood/serum Subcutaneous  Simple I&D    → 20005
• Pus/blood/serum Deep to fascia Complex I&D    → 20010
• Benign skin lesion (cyst, wart, nevus)  Dermis/epidermis → 11400-11446
• Soft-tissue mass (cyst/lipoma) in arm  SubQ/Muscle   → 24071-24079 series
• Bone cyst of humerus (intramedullary)  Bone      → 20055
• Foreign body in muscle/tendon      Past fascia   → 20520/20525

Mnemonic:  
Non-living junk? 20020.  
Living lump or liquid? Look elsewhere.

----------------------------------------------------
5. DOCUMENTATION CHECKLIST—VERIFY BEFORE CODING
☐ Object named and described as inert/non-biologic.  
☐ Location explicitly limited to subcutaneous tissue.  
☐ Incision size ≤1 cm; no extension/undermining.  
☐ No layered closure, drain, or complex repair.

If every box is not checked, 20020 is wrong.

----------------------------------------------------
6. REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES
✓ Correct use:  
“3 mm stab incision over mid-forearm; glass shard retrieved from subcutaneous fat; single 4-0 nylon suture placed. No deep structures violated.” → 20020

✗ Incorrect uses (code shown instead of 20020):  
“2 cm epidermoid cyst excised from forearm subcutaneous tissue” → 24071 (soft-tissue tumor excision, subcutaneous, upper arm).  
“Removal of bullet lodged in deltoid muscle” → 20520 (removal of foreign body, muscle).  
“Corticotomy with curettage of humeral bone cyst” → 20055.  
“Incision and drainage of superficial elbow abscess” → 20005.

----------------------------------------------------
7. QUICK DECISION TREE (poster-worthy)
1. Is it NON-living? If NO → not 20020.  
2. Is it ONLY in fat? If NO → not 20020.  
3. Is incision ≤1 cm, no layered closure? If NO → not 20020.  
All YES → 20020. Done.

----------------------------------------------------
8. MEMORY HOOK
“SEE the splinter, SNIP, SLIP it out—STOP.  
SEE a cyst—STOP faster: find a NEW code.”

Master the S-O-S rule and you’ll never mistake a swimmer’s arm cyst for 20020 again.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: Sugar in the bloodstream can get attached to the hemoglobin in red blood cells. Once the sugar is attached, it stays there for the lifetime of the red blood cell (around 120 days or over 3 months). The higher the amount of blood sugar, the more the quantity of sugar attached to the blood cells. This A1C test measures the amount of sugar sticking to the red blood cells, displaying the result as a percentage. This gives the physician an understanding about the blood sugar level of the patient for the preceding three months. A normal, healthy person should have A1C level below 7%.
CPT.explanation: Code 83036 is for the Hemoglobin A1c test. The other codes are not specific to the Hemoglobin A1c test and represent different laboratory tests.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: The analyst tests for the presence of hemoglobin F, typically in a whole blood sample. The amount is usually very low, except in the newborn infant, in whom almost all the hemoglobin is type F.

Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a procedure involving surgical removal of a part of one of the two lobes the thyroid gland is divided into. The provider may perform the procedure with or without surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60210, refers to a partial thyroidectomy. While 60212 describes a complete thyroid lobectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60225 pertains to a thyroid lobectomy with contralateral subtotal lobectomy. In this scenario, only a partial thyroidectomy was performed, making 60210 the appropriate code.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of a part of one lobe of the thyroid gland and most of the portion of the other lobe of the thyroid gland. The provider also performs surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a procedure involving complete surgical removal of one of the two lobes the thyroid gland is divided into. The provider may perform the procedure with or without surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 60220  
Thyroid lobectomy, unilateral; TOTAL lobectomy (entire lobe removed), with or without removal of the isthmus.

Key Points for Accurate Use  
1. “Total lobectomy” = the ENTIRE lobe is taken out. If the operative note says the surgeon removed the whole right or left lobe, choose 60220.  
2. The term “lobectomy” in the endocrine surgery literature almost always means the whole lobe unless the surgeon explicitly states “partial.” Do not assume “lobectomy” is partial.

Commonly Confused Codes  
• 60210 – PARTIAL thyroid lobectomy, unilateral, with or without isthmusectomy. Use when only a PORTION of one lobe is excised (e.g., upper pole resection, wedge resection).  
• 60212 – TOTAL lobectomy on one side + SUBTOTAL lobectomy on the opposite side (used in staged/extent-of-disease cases).  
• 60225 – TOTAL lobectomy on one side + PARTIAL lobectomy on the opposite side.  
• 60240 – Total thyroidectomy (both lobes completely removed).  
• 60100 – Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of thyroid; no open resection.

Quick Decision Checklist  
A. Entire gland removed? → 60240  
B. One entire lobe removed? → 60220  
C. Only part of one lobe removed? → 60210  
D. One entire lobe + some of the contralateral lobe removed?  
 • Subtotal other side → 60212  
 • Partial other side  → 60225  
E. Needle biopsy only? → 60100

Documentation Tips  
• Look for operative phrases such as “complete removal of the right lobe,” “total lobectomy,” or “remaining thyroid tissue on that side was excised in its entirety.”  
• If the report says “partial lobectomy,” “hemithyroidectomy” with residual tissue, or specifies a polar/segmental resection, it is NOT 60220.  
• Verify whether the isthmus was removed; it does NOT change the code selection for 60210 or 60220.

Coder’s Warning  
The most frequent error is defaulting to 60210 whenever the word “lobectomy” appears. Always confirm whether the entire lobe was removed. If the surgeon is ambiguous, query for clarification before coding.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of one whole lobe of the thyroid gland and most of the other lobe of the thyroid gland. The provider also performs surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60210, refers to a partial thyroidectomy. While 60212 describes a complete thyroid lobectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60225 pertains to a thyroid lobectomy with contralateral subtotal lobectomy. In this scenario, only a partial thyroidectomy was performed, making 60210 the appropriate code.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider examines the kidney for diagnostic purposes, without any curative surgical intervention, such as inspection for hemorrhage, urinary leakage, or tissue damage due to trauma.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50010, refers to renal exploratory surgery. 50220 describes a nephrectomy, 50200 is for a renal biopsy, and 50398 describes an injection procedure for antegrade nephrostogram and/or ureterogram.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider drains an abscess from the kidney (renal) or the area surrounding the kidney (perirenal) with an open approach.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50543, refers to a percutaneous nephrostolithotomy or pyelostolithotomy. The other codes are: 50010 - Renal exploratory surgery, 50020 - Renal abscess drainage, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: In this procedure.  A physician inserts a collection needle into the kidney to collect a sample for further diagnostic biopsy.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Laparoscopic Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider uses a surgical laparoscopic technique to remove part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50543, refers to a percutaneous nephrostolithotomy or pyelostolithotomy. The other codes are: 50010 - Renal exploratory surgery, 50020 - Renal abscess drainage, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: Nephrectomy is a surgical procedure for removal of a kidney or part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50200, refers to a renal biopsy. The other codes are: 50220 - Nephrectomy, 50225 - Delayed nephrostogram, and 50230 - Nephrectomy, partial.

The correct code, 50010, refers to renal exploratory surgery. 50220 describes a nephrectomy, 50200 is for a renal biopsy, and 50398 describes an injection procedure for antegrade nephrostogram and/or ureterogram.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Nose Summary: In this procedure, the provider aspirates the excess fluid from within the nasal cavity, which may be due to an abscess or hematoma.
Excision Procedures on the Nose Summary: This CPT code is for a submucous resection of the inferior turbinate (partial or complete by any method).
Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity to examine the structures of the nasal cavity on one or both sides.
CPT.explanation: 31231 is the CPT code for nasal endoscopy, diagnostic, unilateral or bilateral (separate procedure).

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. She examines the nasal contents. The provider then performs a nasal biopsy, polypectomy, or debridement.
Incision Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an intranasal incision. The provider then uses cutting forceps to perform a middle meatal sinusotomy.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. He then gains access to the maxillary sinus through a cut in the uncinate process. The provider opens the maxillary sinus.
CPT.explanation:
31256 ‒ Nasal/Sinus Endoscopy, Surgical; WITH MAXILLARY ANTROSTOMY  
(Endoscopic middle-meatal antrostomy)

What the code represents  
• Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) performed trans-nasally with a rigid/flexible endoscope.  
• The surgeon enters the middle meatus, removes the uncinate process if necessary, identifies the NATURAL ostium of the maxillary sinus, and enlarges it to improve ventilation/drainage.  
• No external (facial) or intra-oral incision is made.

Included services (bundled)  
– Diagnostic nasal endoscopy  
– Uncinectomy / uncinate process resection  
– Limited removal of bone or mucosa needed only to create the opening  
– Hemostasis and simple postoperative debridement

When to code something else  
31267  – If the surgeon also removes significant diseased tissue, polyps, or fungal debris from INSIDE the maxillary sinus.  
31020  – Open (non-endoscopic) Caldwell-Luc maxillary sinusotomy via a sublabial or facial incision with removal of the anterior-inferior sinus wall. No scope = no 31256.  
31287 / 31288 – Endoscopic SPHENOIDOTOMY procedures.  
31254 / 31255 – Endoscopic ETHMOIDECTOMY procedures.

Key documentation words that support 31256  
“Endoscopic,” “transnasal,” “middle meatal antrostomy,” “natural ostium enlarged,” “FESS,” “uncinectomy.”  
Red flags that point to 31020 instead: “Caldwell-Luc,” “sublabial incision,” “gingivobuccal incision,” “anterior wall removed.”

Real-world example  
Operative note: “Using a 0° endoscope, the uncinate process was removed. The natural ostium of the right maxillary sinus was identified and widened to 10 mm for drainage.”  → 31256.

Quick check  
Is an endoscope documented? YES → 31 256.  
Was the sinus entered through an open sublabial or facial incision? YES → 31 020, not 31 256.

Use this distinction—ENDOSCOPIC vs. OPEN approach—to avoid the common 31020/31256 mix-up.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity and creates an opening in the sphenoid sinus.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. The provider widens the sphenoid sinus opening. He then removes tissues from the sphenoid sinus.
Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of the entire thyroid gland.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a diagnostic procedure in which the provider removes a tissue sample from the thyroid gland, typically under imaging guidance, using an automatic, spring–powered core needle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Parathyroid, Thymus, Adrenal Glands, Pancreas, and Carotid Body Summary: In the traditional procedure of parathyroid exploration, the provider surgically visualizes and screens the parathyroid glands for pathology based on their appearance and relative size. He may then perform parathyroidectomy, which is surgical removal of one or more parathyroid glands as indicated. The glands are a set of four small glands situated on the rear of the four corners of the butterfly shaped thyroid gland.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60500, refers to a parathyroidectomy. While 60212 and 60240 are associated with thyroid procedures (thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy and total thyroidectomy respectively), 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy. The scenario specifies a procedure on the parathyroid, making 60500 the accurate code.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: The provider takes at least three X–ray images of a patient’s complete wrist to check for any fracture, swelling, or reason of pain in the wrist area.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: In this procedure, the provider takes two X–ray images of a patient’s wrist to check for any fracture, swelling, or reason of pain in the wrist area.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: X–rays of the extremities have been performed to assess injury, fracture, arthritis, bone spurs, tumors, or congenital abnormalities. Extremity X–rays include the hand, wrist, arm, foot, ankle, hip, leg, shoulder, or knee. X–rays of the affected site focus on the specific area that is injured or damaged.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs imaging supervision and interpretation for a wrist joint study. The provider injects contrast material or air into the patient’s wrist joint and takes a series of X–rays as it flows through the joint to evaluate the different joint structures for conditions such as arthritis, adhesive capsulitis, or a frozen joint, tears, or abnormalities of the cartilage. Report this code to represent only imaging supervision and interpretation for this procedure.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Excision and Destruction Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider excises a lesion or area of damaged or diseased tissue of the mucosa, a membrane lining the anterior most part of the mouth, and the submucosa, the layer beneath the mucosa. This procedure involves a simple repair of the surgical wound.
Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs an incision in the floor of the mouth and excises tissue for the purpose of biopsy.

Excision and Destruction Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider removes the labial or buccal frenum, each of which is a membrane structure in the mouth. Labial refers to the lip and buccal refers to the cheek.

Endoscopy-Cystoscopy, Urethroscopy, Cystourethroscopy Procedures on the Bladder Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs an examination of the interior of the bladder, the urethra, and the ureteric openings by means of a cystourethroscope, a thin flexible or rigid tube with a camera on one end.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 52000, pertains to cystourethroscopy. The other codes are: 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: Cryoablation or cryosurgery is a procedure in which very low temperatures are used to destroy a mass lesion, tumor cells, or cancer cells by freezing them. In this procedure cold is introduced to the intended target through a probe containing liquid nitrogen that is inserted into the kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: The provider performs anterior and posterior ethmoidectomy (removal or excision of cells in the ethmoid bone or ethmoid sinus), generally performed if the anterior part and the posterior compartment of ethmoid sinus are involved with sinusitis.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. She then gains access to the maxillary sinus through a cut in the uncinate process. The provider opens the maxillary sinus and removes diseased tissues.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the frontal sinus to explore it for abnormalities. The provider may also remove bone, scar tissue, polyps, or other tissue from the frontal sinus.
Renal Transplantation Procedures Summary: Nephrectomy is a surgical procedure for removal of a kidney or part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50430, refers to injection procedure for retrograde pyelography. The other codes are: 50320 - Renal autotransplantation, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50390 - Aspiration of kidney cyst.

CPT.description: Other Renal Introduction (Injection/Change/Removal) Procedures Summary: The provider creates a new access route percutaneously (through a small incision made in the patient’s skin) and injects contrast material into the ureters (ureterogram) or kidney (nephrostogram) to analyze the internal structures of the kidneys, renal pelvis, and/or ureters using imaging guidance. The provider typically performs this procedure to assess nephrostomy or pyelostomy tube function, identify blockage in the ureteropelvic junction, or check for urine leakage around the tube insertion site. The procedure covers the complete diagnostic procedure and all radiological supervision and interpretation.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50430, refers to injection procedure for retrograde pyelography. The other codes are: 50320 - Renal autotransplantation, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50390 - Aspiration of kidney cyst.

CPT.description: Other Renal Introduction (Injection/Change/Removal) Procedures Summary: The provider aspirates, or drains, a renal cyst or injects the cyst with a fluid. Aspiration is mainly performed by injecting a sclerotic agent, such as an acetic acid or ethanol into the renal cyst when the cyst causes abdominal pain, repeated urination, or hematuria.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50430, refers to injection procedure for retrograde pyelography. The other codes are: 50320 - Renal autotransplantation, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50390 - Aspiration of kidney cyst.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: Preventive medicine services are provided to individuals who are not in need of any immediate medical attention, but need to undergo a periodic health checkup as a preventive measure. Well–baby visits, well–woman visits, and routine annual physical check–ups come under the purview of preventive medicine reevaluation and management services. These visits are different from other visits where the patient has a problem for which medical attention is sought. The age, gender, and associated risk factors of the person are important considerations while providing a preventive medicine service. The physician performs a comprehensive review of systems, comprehensive past family and social history (PFSH), and makes a thorough assessment of age and gender–related risk factors. The physician may order and obtain diagnostic/laboratory procedures and administer immunizations during the preventive service.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider performs a well–patient visit for a child who is between the ages of 1 and 4 who meets the definition of new patient.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: Preventive medicine services are provided to individuals who are not in need of any immediate medical attention, but need to undergo a periodic health checkup as a preventive measure. Well–baby visits, well–woman visits, and routine annual physical check–ups come under the purview of preventive medicine reevaluation and management services. These visits are different from other visits where the patient has a problem for which medical attention is sought. The age, gender, and associated risk factors of the person are important considerations while providing a preventive medicine service. The physician performs a comprehensive review of systems, comprehensive past family and social history (PFSH), and makes a thorough assessment of age and gender–related risk factors. The physician may order and obtain diagnostic/laboratory procedures and administer immunizations during the preventive service.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider performs a well–baby visit for a child under the age of one.
CPT.explanation:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
CPT 99381-99397  |  Preventive Medicine, Initial/Periodic
(Well-baby, well-child, annual physical, sports or school physical, etc.)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

THE “NO-EXCUSES” RULE
Preventive medicine codes fire ONLY when the chart documents BOTH of the
following on the date of service:

1.  Patient status to THIS practice/specialty  
    • NEW  = no face-to-face visit in the past 3 yrs → 9938x series  
    • EST  = seen face-to-face within 3 yrs        → 9939x series  

2.  Exact chronologic AGE on the service date—nothing else.  
    Age alone selects the last digit of the code.

         NEW PATIENT                ESTABLISHED PATIENT
   < 1 yr   99381                < 1 yr   99391
   1-4 yr   99382                1-4 yr   99392
   5-11 yr  99383                5-11 yr  99393
   12-17 yr 99384                12-17 yr 99394
   18-39 yr 99385                18-39 yr 99395
   40-64 yr 99386                40-64 yr 99396
   65+ yr   99387                65+ yr   99397

ABSOLUTE RULE:  NO DOCUMENTED AGE/DATE-OF-BIRTH → NO 9938x/9939x CODE.  
Do not “reverse engineer” age from words like “annual,” grade level,
immunization schedule, or the mere presence of parents. Either locate an
explicit age/DOB or mark “information insufficient.”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
WHAT’S ALREADY INCLUDED
• Comprehensive, age-appropriate history & exam
• Anticipatory guidance / risk-factor reduction counseling
• Ordering of routine lab & immunizations

Therefore: Phrases such as “comprehensive PF/SH/FH obtained” NEVER change
the code. They are baked into every preventive E/M.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
ADD-ON OR SEPARATE CODES
• New/established PROBLEM evaluated on same DOS and significant beyond
  “minor/self-limited”?  Bill 9920x-9921x with modifier ‑25.  
• Immunization admin (90460-90474) & vaccine supply (90476-90759) may be
  billed separately when performed/documented.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
COMMON TRAPS & HOW TO AVOID THEM
1. “Annual,” “routine,” “sports physical” ≠ NEW. These words only prove
   the patient is ESTABLISHED; they do not reveal age.  
2. Infant trap: 9-month-old = “<1 yr,” not “1-4 yr.”  
3. Missing age = automatic stop. Selecting any 9939x digit without a
   documented age is 100 % wrong on exams and in real claims.  
4. Coding by history depth = wrong paradigm (applies to 99202-99215,
   not preventive codes).  
5. Same-day illness (e.g., ear pain) requires a separate, supported
   problem-oriented E/M + ‑25, not a higher preventive code.  
6. “Which code represents this level of history?”—classic test trick.
   If age is absent, the safest answer is “cannot be determined.”

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
LOOK-ALIKES & QUICK DIFFERENTIATORS
• 99202-99215 Office/Outpatient E/M: chief complaint/diagnosis-driven,
  history & exam are selected by medical necessity, not age.  
• 99401-99404 Preventive counseling ONLY: no comprehensive exam performed.  
• 99455-99456 Work/Disability evals.  
• 99460-99463 Newborn inpatient preventive: hospital or birthing center,
  not office.  

Memory hook:  STATUS + AGE, or walk away.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
SPEED-CHECK EXAMPLES
• First-time visit, 9-month-old → NEW <1 yr → 99381.  
• 3-yr-old yearly well-child, seen last year → EST 1-4 yr → 99392.  
• 15-yr-old, chart silent on prior care → assume NEW 12-17 yr → 99384.  
• 46-yr-old new patient physical → NEW 40-64 yr → 99386.  
• Vignette lacks age → do NOT guess; answer “coding indeterminable.”

Sticky-note rule:  If AGE isn’t written, the code isn’t either.

Payers typically consider 80050 to apply only when the clinician orders the general health panel specifically as a screening, so the panel code would not apply when the clinician orders the component tests for diagnostic purposes.

He performs this procedure without using contrast material. He then follows with contrast material and takes more images.

The visit involves a straightforward or low level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 40 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a high level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 75 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
99223 – CPT 99223  
Initial Hospital Inpatient OR Observation Care – Level 3
“The HIGH-MDM / 75-MINUTE admit”

====================================================================
1. 2024 ONE-LINE DEFINITION  
First-calendar-day admission or observation visit by the attending provider that involves EITHER  
• High-complexity medical decision making (MDM), OR  
• ≥ 75 minutes of that provider’s total work on the date of service.

H = H igh MDM or H our-plus (75+ min) → 99223

====================================================================
2. AUDIT-PROOF CHECKLIST  

A. BILLING GATEKEEPERS  
□ Signed admit/obs order dated & time-stamped.  
□ You are the admitting/attending provider for that day.

B. LEVEL BY MDM  – ALL THREE ELEMENTS MUST HIT “HIGH”  

                      99221          99222           99223  
Problems             Low            Moderate         High / life- or organ-threat  
Data                 Limited        Moderate         Extensive (multiple sources, imaging, labs, discussions)  
Risk                 Low            Moderate         High / imminent threat, high-risk meds, emergency surgery, etc.

C. LEVEL BY TIME  – WHEN TOTAL WORK ≥ 75 MIN  

99221  40–54 min | 99222  55–74 min | 99223  75 min+  
Document: “Total time personally spent today ____ minutes (>50 % counseling/coordination).”  
Count ALL same-day work: chart review, bedside, family calls, orders, documentation, care coordination.

D. HISTORY & EXAM – STILL REQUIRED, NO LONGER LEVELED  
Must be “medically appropriate.” Depth (problem-focused vs extended vs comprehensive) does NOT change the CPT code after 1-Jan-2023.

====================================================================
3. DO-NOT-FALL-FOR-THESE TRAPS  

1. “Detailed history + detailed exam = 99221.”  WRONG!  
   History/exam bullets were deleted from inpatient leveling in 2023. Code is chosen ONLY by MDM OR total time.

2. Copy-and-paste full ROS just to “earn” 99223.  Unnecessary and risky. Audit focus is on MDM/time and clinical relevance.

3. Using extinct code 99220 (deleted 1-Jan-2023).  High-severity observation admits are now 99223.

4. Billing 99223 on subsequent days (use 99231-99233) or same-day admit/discharge (use 99234-99236).

====================================================================
4. INSTANT DECISION FLOW  

1. Admit/obs order & you are the attending? — NO → pick consult, ED, or subsequent codes.  
2. ≥ 75 minutes total today? — YES → 99223 (document time).  
3. If < 75 min, is MDM high? — YES → 99223.  
4. Otherwise: moderate = 99222; low = 99221.

====================================================================
5. MINI-CASE CLARIFIERS  

Chest-pain myths exposed:  
• Example 1 – Chest pain, troponin 14 ng/mL, ST depressions, heparin + cath lab planned. High risk → 99223 (high MDM).  
• Example 2 – Chest wall strain, normal ECG, no high-risk meds. Low MDM, 48 min. → 99221.  
• Example 3 – Same scenario as Q-bank error: “extended history, detailed exam,” but uncomplicated costochondritis, 20 min, low data, low risk. → 99221, NOT 99223. Reason: NOT high MDM and NOT 75 min, regardless of examination depth.

====================================================================
6. QUICK CROSS-WALK  

Code  Select by MDM  Select by Time  
99221 Low       40–54 min  
99222 Moderate     55–74 min  
99223 High       75 min +

====================================================================
7. BOTTOM-LINE PEARL  
NEVER assign 99223 because the history or exam looks “comprehensive.”  
Assign 99223 only when you can say, “This case was HIGH-RISK or I personally spent ≥ 75 minutes today.”

CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99222 is for an expanded problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

The visit involves a straightforward level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 10 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: The provider sees an established patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a low level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 20 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 99213  –  Established patient, Office/Outpatient visit  
Current (2021-forward) E/M rules

1. What qualifies?
   • EITHER Low-level Medical Decision Making (MDM) – OR – 20-29 minutes of total physician/qualified health-care professional (QHP) time on the date of service.  
   • History and examination are performed “as medically appropriate” but are NOT scored. Do not try to count HPI elements or exam bullets; that methodology was retired.

2. Key components for LOW-LEVEL MDM  
   • 2 or more self-limited or minor problems ‑OR- 1 stable chronic illness ‑OR- 1 acute, uncomplicated illness or injury.  
   • Limited data review/ordering (e.g., 1 external note, 1 test, or simple lab panel).  
   • Low risk of morbidity (OTC treatment, simple prescription management, physical therapy, etc.).

3. Typical visit clues
   • Follow-up for hypertension, reflux, mild asthma, minor rash, medication adjustment, etc.  
   • Physician reviews current meds, asks about symptom progress, performs a focused exam, possibly orders/refills a routine prescription.

4. Typical total time
   • 20–29 minutes spent face-to-face AND/OR on the same day in chart review, documentation, orders, patient communication, etc.

5. Common confusions

   99212  (Straightforward MDM or 10-19 min)  
   • Usually 1 self-limited/minor problem, no prescription management, minimal data reviewed.  
   • Example: re-check of a resolved URI, advice to continue home care, no new meds.

   99214  (Moderate MDM or 30-39 min)  
   • 1 chronic illness with exacerbation or 2+ stable chronic illnesses, or acute illness with systemic symptoms; moderate data; moderate drug-therapy risk.  
   • Example: uncontrolled diabetes requiring med change and review of CMP, A1c, and ophthalmology note.

   99215  (High MDM or 40-54 min)  
   • Severe exacerbations, high-risk medication monitoring (e.g., warfarin with INR issues), decision regarding hospitalization, extensive data review.

   Warning: A “limited exam” plus med review does NOT automatically equal 99212. If prescription drug management is involved or if two minor problems are addressed, LOW-level MDM is met → 99213.

6. Documentation tips
   • State problems addressed and status.  
   • Note any prescription changes or counseling.  
   • Briefly list data reviewed/ordered.  
   • Record total time when selecting code by time.

7. Do not down-code
   • If you meet LOW-level MDM (or 20-29 min) but document 99212, revenue is lost and quality measures may be impacted.

Mnemonic: “1 stable problem + Rx = 213” (read “2-13”).
