Other Procedures on the Nose Summary: The provider uses a complex or extensive approach to stop a heavy nosebleed caused by a vessel in the front area of the nose.
CPT.explanation: 30903 is the CPT code for control nasal hemorrhage, posterior, complex (e.g., therapeutic endoscopy, posterior nasal packs).

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this diagnostic procedure, the provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of the thorax without using contrast material.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this diagnostic procedure, the provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of the thorax using contrast material.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this diagnostic procedure, the provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of the thorax without using contrast material. He then follows with contrast material and takes more images.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs a computed tomographic angiography, or CTA imaging of the chest to get detailed images of the blood vessels but not the heart. He performs this study using a contrast material injection and may also take non contrast images of the blood vessels as well.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of techniques for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session with the patient typically lasts for anywhere between16 to 37 minutes.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 90832 is used to describe individual psychotherapy for 30 minutes. The other codes are for different durations or types of psychotherapy sessions.

CPT.description: Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of techniques for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session with the patient typically lasts for anywhere between 38 to 52 minutes.

Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of technique for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session typically lasts for a minimum of 53 minutes or more.

Psychotherapy for Crisis Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy for a crisis situation when the patient is in a life–threatening state and needs immediate attention. The treatment session typically lasts anywhere between 30 to 74 minutes.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the colon and rectum using a colonoscope, a flexible tube with a camera at its inserted end. If he sees any areas of abnormal mucosa or tissue, he takes samples using a brush passed through the scope or irrigates the area with warm saline and aspirates the washings through the scope. He sends the specimens to the laboratory for diagnostic analysis.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the colon and rectum using a colonoscope, a tubular instrument with a light source and camera, which he inserts through the rectum to look for a blockage. He identifies and removes foreign bodies, such as swallowed objectives that could damage or obstruct the colon.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the rectum and colon using a flexible colonoscope, a tubular instrument with a light source and camera, to look for the cause of a patient's symptoms, which may include diarrhea, constipation, rectal bleeding, or abdominal pain. He excises one or more suspicious areas of tissue using biopsy forceps and submits the specimens for laboratory analysis.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider inserts a flexible endoscope into the anus and navigates the scope through the entire colon. The provider performs one or more injections into the submucosa (the tissue below the mucous membrane).
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a moderate level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 55 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99222 is for an expanded problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT.description: Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an intraocular lens prosthesis after extracapsular cataract extraction using complex techniques and devices. He may perform this by means of an iris expansion device, providing support to the intraocular lens, or capsulorrhexis. This procedure is done without the use of an endoscopic laser probe to shrink the ciliary processes, a procedure to treat glaucoma.

Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an artificial lens after removing an extracapsular cataract by aspiration or use of ultrasonic waves. This procedure is done without the use of an endoscopic laser probe to shrink the ciliary processes, a procedure to treat glaucoma.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 66984 represents extracapsular cataract removal with insertion of intraocular lens prosthesis. The other options are other ophthalmologic procedures but not specific to the described scenario.

CPT.description: Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider removes the cataract lens and capsule as one and then inserts a lens prosthesis. The goal of the procedure is to correct a cataract, an opacity of the lens that affects the vision of the eye.
Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an intraocular lens into the eye of a patient who had previously had cataract removal.

Hematology and Coagulation Procedures Summary: The lab analyst performs a blood count on the red and white blood cells and platelets also known as thrombocytes. He also determines the hemoglobin, typically by spectrophotometry, and the hematocrit, or packed red cell volume, by calculation in a whole blood sample.
CPT.explanation: Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.

CPT.description: Hematology and Coagulation Procedures Summary: A complete blood count (better known as a CBC) is a blood test request by a doctor that provides detailed information about various types of cells in a patient's blood. Usually a pathologist or a technician conducts the test and provides the results of CBC to the requesting doctor. The blood is drawn from the patient's vein using a syringe and is stored in a test tube containing an anticoagulant (usually EDTA or citrate) to prevent clotting and transported to laboratory.  Nowadays, most often, the cell counting process is done in an automated way using an instrument known as an "automated analyzer". The automatic cell counter counts the number of different cells in the blood and the results are printed out for review by the physician.
CPT.explanation: Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.
Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.
Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Lower Abdomen Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for an extraperitoneal procedure in lower abdomen, including the urinary tract.
CPT.explanation: Code 00860 is used for anesthesia during lower abdominal procedures, including obstetric ultrasonography. Code 00864 represents anesthesia during cesarean delivery, 00862 during vaginal delivery, and 00868 during advanced labor and delivery procedures.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Lower Abdomen Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for an extraperitoneal procedure in the lower abdomen, including urinary tract; total cystectomy.
CPT.explanation: Code 00860 is used for anesthesia during lower abdominal procedures, including obstetric ultrasonography. Code 00864 represents anesthesia during cesarean delivery, 00862 during vaginal delivery, and 00868 during advanced labor and delivery procedures.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Lower Abdomen Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for an extraperitoneal procedure in the lower abdomen, including the urinary tract; renal procedures, including upper one third of ureter, or donor nephrectomy.
CPT.explanation: Code 00860 is used for anesthesia during lower abdominal procedures, including obstetric ultrasonography. Code 00864 represents anesthesia during cesarean delivery, 00862 during vaginal delivery, and 00868 during advanced labor and delivery procedures.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Lower Abdomen Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing a renal transplant.
CPT.explanation: Code 00860 is used for anesthesia during lower abdominal procedures, including obstetric ultrasonography. Code 00864 represents anesthesia during cesarean delivery, 00862 during vaginal delivery, and 00868 during advanced labor and delivery procedures.

CPT.description: Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: The provider or technician administers a spirometry test to assess the patient's respiratory function. The spirometer is attached to a computer that records the total and timed vital capacity (maximum expired air) and expiratory flow rate (speed of expiration) and displays the results as a graph. The patient may or may not be required to exhale rapidly over 12 to 15 seconds after deep breathing.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 94010 represents spirometry, including graphic record, total and timed vital capacity, expiratory flow rate measurement(s), with or without maximal voluntary ventilation. The other codes are for different types or parts of pulmonary function tests.

CPT.description: Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: The spirometry test is performed with a spirometer. The instrument displays a graphical representation, known as a spirogram, of the test results. The basic forced volume vital capacity (FVC) test is done by asking the patient to inhale and exhale air through the sensors of the device. The speed and volume of the air is measured and the result is displayed on a graph. A bronchodilator drug is also given to the patient and the spirometry test is performed before and after the drug administration to find out the difference between results obtained in two different phases. The difference in results helps to deduce the responsiveness of the respiratory system to the bronchodilator.

Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: In this procedure, the provider deliberately induces bronchospasm by controlled and measurable exposure to a specific stimulant. He then performs spirometry multiple times to evaluate the lung function under induced bronchospasm.

Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: This procedure requires the patient to perform spirometry at a predetermined time each day. The patient records the spirometry findings over a period of 30 days and includes hook–up of spirometer, education on spirometer’s use, spirometric tracing, data capture, trend analysis, and periodic recalibration. This code represents the technical component of the service only.

Wound Exploration-Trauma (eg, Penetrating Gunshot, Stab Wound) Procedures on the Musculoskeletal System Summary: The provider explores a penetrating wound in the neck, such as from a sharp object or gunshot, to assess and repair internal damage and remove any foreign material retained in the wound.
CPT.explanation:
20100 – INCISION & DRAINAGE, DEEP ABSCESS / HEMATOMA  
           SOFT-TISSUE OF THE POSTERIOR TRUNK   (AND NOWHERE ELSE)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
WHY THIS PAGE WAS REWRITTEN  
On recent exams a hematoma “over the shoulder” was coded with 20100 simply because the correct shoulder-only code (23030) was missing from the answer list.  The real solution was to pick 20016 (intramuscular upper-arm/shoulder area), not to default to 20100.  
This update drills in three points:  
1. 20100 = posterior-trunk ONLY.  
2. The anatomic “shoebox” for 20100 stops at the scapular spine and NEVER crosses onto the shoulder girdle.  
3. If 23030 is absent, fall back to the next best SHOULDER/UPPER-ARM code (usually 20016, rarely 20010)―but never to 20100.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
1. PLAIN-LANGUAGE DEFINITION (UNCHANGED)  
A scalpel cut that starts on the back, penetrates skin, subQ fat, and the investing fascia, and ends inside or between the paraspinal muscles to evacuate pus or blood.  A drain is almost always placed.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
2. THE “BACK-SHOEBOX”—NOW WITH A HARD FRONT WALL  
• Patient prone  
• Ceiling – External occipital protuberance  
• Floor   – Top of the inter-gluteal cleft  
• Side walls – Right & left mid-axillary lines  
• FRONT WALL – Scapular spines and posterior axillary folds  
If ANY part of the incision crosses that front wall (i.e., onto the scapula, acromion, deltoid, axilla), 20100 is WRONG.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
3. NEW HOT-SPOT MAP—SHOULDER FAMILY CODES

Region                       Deep I&D Code          Notes  
──────────────────────────── ─────────────── ──────────────────────────────  
Shoulder / Scapula           23030             Gold-standard shoulder code  
PROXIMAL Upper Arm / Deltoid 20016             Use when 23030 absent AND op note confirms
                                              intramuscular or subfascial work in deltoid  
Distal Upper Arm / Elbow     20010             Deep, but distal to deltoid insertion  
Posterior Trunk (true back)  20100             ONLY inside the back-shoebox  

Mnemonic: “Scapula seen?  23-0-30.  Scapula code gone?  20-0-16.  Never 20-1-00.”

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
4. REVISED DEPTH / LOCATION WORK-FLOW

STEP 1 – Ask LOCATION first  
• In the back-shoebox? → go to Step 2  
• On or anterior to scapular spine? → shoulder/upper-arm family (23030 ▶ 20016 ▶ 20010)  
• Buttock / hip? → 27301  
• Lateral chest / axilla? → 21501  
• Abd wall / flank? → 21935  

STEP 2 – Ask DEPTH next  
• Skin / subQ only → 10180  
• Fascia breached → verify abscess or hematoma  
• Seroma / cyst / foreign body → different code set  

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
5. DOCUMENTATION THAT “LOCKS IN” 20100 (UNCHANGED)  
✓ Exact location inside shoebox (e.g., “4 cm left of L3 spinous process”)  
✓ Investing fascia incised (thoracolumbar, lumbodorsal, etc.)  
✓ Abscess or hematoma evacuated (+/– drain)  

MISS **ANY** OF THE ABOVE?  DO NOT USE 20100.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
6. EXAM-STYLE PRACTICE—NOW INCLUDING THE SHOULDER TRAP  

A. “Incision 5 cm over posterior deltoid; fascia opened, clot evacuated.”  
   – Shoulder girdle, not true back.  
   – If 23030 offered → PICK IT.  
   – If NOT, look for 20016 before 20010.  NEVER 20100.  

B. “Midline T12 incision; thoracolumbar fascia opened; purulence expressed; drain left.”  
   – Checks all three boxes → 20100.  

C. “Incision over scapular spine with deep hematoma evacuation.”  
   – 23030 (shoulder), not 20100.  

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
7. ONE-LINE MEMORY AID (UPDATED)  
“Back-box ONLY = 20100.  
Touch the scapula?  Try 23030—then 20016—then 20010, but NEVER 20100.”

Post this, circle the “shoulder trap,” and you will never dump a shoulder hematoma into the posterior-trunk code again.

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider may extract the contents of an acne lesion with a suction–type instrument or excise or perform marsupialization on larger lesions or cysts.
CPT.explanation:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
CPT 10040   •   ACNE SURGERY  
“Mechanical opening and immediate expression of MULTIPLE acne-type lesions
in a SINGLE encounter.”  ‑- Bill ONE unit per session, no matter how many
lesions are treated.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1.  WHAT THE CODE ACTUALLY PAYS FOR
    • Lesion types: open or closed comedones, pustules, milia, very
      superficial epidermal inclusion cysts.  
    • Technique: tiny puncture / nick / stab incision → immediate
      expression with a comedone extractor, needle, lancet, curette,
      loop, etc.  
    • No tissue destruction, no margins removed, no specimen sent to
      pathology.

2.  GREEN-LIGHT CONDITIONS (ALL MUST BE PRESENT)
    □ Chief complaint = acneiform eruption (L70.0-L70.9, L72.0, Q82.8).  
    □ Documentation uses “opened,” “punctured,” “expressed,” or
      “comedone extraction” AND makes it clear that more than one lesion
      was treated.  
    □ Same visit, same body area; total time usually ≤ 15 min.  

3.  BRIGHT-RED “DO-NOT-USE-10040” SITUATIONS
    ✘ Any wart / verruca / HPV lesion (see Section 4).  
    ✘ Any destructive method (cryotherapy, electrodessication,
      trichloroacetic acid, laser, photodynamic, chemical peel).  
    ✘ Excision with margins, layered closure, or specimen for
      histology.  
    ✘ Incision & drainage of an abscess, furuncle, carbuncle, paronychia
      (use 10060-10061).  
    ✘ Removal of a foreign body (10120-10121).  
    ✘ Skin tags, seborrheic keratoses, angiomas, molluscum contagiosum,
      etc. (see 11200, 17110-17111, 11400-11446).

4.  “LOOK-ALIKE / SOUND-ALIKE” CHEAT SHEET
    • Wart (verruca) ‑- Destruction ≤14 lesions  → 17110  
                         Destruction ≥15 lesions → 17111  
                         Excision (any #)        → 11400-11446 (size &
                         site driven)  
      Rule of Thumb: If the note says “wart,” **slam the door on 10040**.  

    • Skin tag removal (up to 15)……………… 11200  
    • Abscess I&D (one simple)……………… 10060  
    • Drainage of complex abscess……… 10061  
    • Foreign-body removal………………… 10120 / 10121  

5.  DOCUMENTATION BLUEPRINT (COPY-PASTE-READY)
    “After cleansing with alcohol, 18-gauge needle used to puncture 10
    closed comedones and 4 milia on bilateral cheeks. Immediate, gentle
    expression achieved with comedone extractor. No tissue destruction,
    no specimen sent. Patient tolerated well; post-care discussed.”

6.  REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES
    ✓ Correct 10040:  
      “Expressed 22 comedones on back using loop extractor.” → 10040 x 1  
    ✗ NOT 10040:  
      “Shaved 1 verruca vulgaris R index finger, sent to path.”  
      Correct code = 11422 (benign excision, hand, 1.1-2.0 cm).  

7.  MODIFIER & BUNDLING PEARLS
    • Global period = 0 days.  
    • Add E/M +-25 only if a separately identifiable visit is
      documented (new Dx, med management, etc.).  
    • Add ‑59/-XS ONLY when 10040 is done on acne lesions and another
      integumentary procedure is done on a different lesion or site.  

8.  30-SECOND DECISION ALGORITHM
       Step 1  What is the lesion?  
                Wart/skin tag/keratosis → STOP, go to 17110-17111 or
                114xx.  
                Abscess → 10060/10061.  
                Foreign body → 10120/10121.  
                Acne/pustule/milia → Step 2.  
       Step 2  How many lesions punctured & expressed today?  
                2+ lesions → 10040.  
                1 purulent cavity → 10060.  
                1 non-purulent comedone → bundle into E/M.  

9.  MEMORY TRIGGERS
    • “10040 has two zeros = **two or more** pimples opened.”  
    • “See the word ‘wart’? Walk away from 10040—go to 17110/11400.”

Keep this card in your pocket: it saves denials and prevents the #1
exam error—coding a wart as acne surgery.

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider removes a foreign body such as a thorn, piece of wood, sliver of glass or fishook, from the lower layer of skin.
CPT.explanation: 10120 is the CPT code for incision and removal of foreign body, subcutaneous tissues; simple.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of the thyroid gland including its extension into the thorax below the sternum.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60101, represents a core needle biopsy of the thyroid. The codes 60100 and 60240 respectively describe a fine needle aspiration biopsy and a total thyroidectomy. The code 60271 pertains to a thyroidectomy for malignancy, without radical neck dissection. In this case, a core needle biopsy was performed, making 60101 the suitable code.

The correct code, 60101, represents a core needle biopsy of the thyroid. The codes 60100 and 60240 respectively describe a fine needle aspiration biopsy and a total thyroidectomy. The code 60271 pertains to a thyroidectomy for malignancy, without radical neck dissection. In this case, a core needle biopsy was performed, making 60101 the suitable code.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Knee and Popliteal Area Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing an open or arthroscopic total knee arthroplasty.
CPT.explanation: Code 01400 is appropriate for anesthesia during knee joint procedures. Code 01402 is more specific to tibia and fibula procedures, 01404 to foot and ankle procedures, and 01406 to total ankle replacement surgeries.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Knee and Popliteal Area Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing an open or arthroscopic procedure on the knee joint.
CPT.explanation:
01400 – Anesthesia for OPEN or ARTHROSCOPIC procedures on the KNEE JOINT  
 • Includes: meniscectomy, ligament reconstruction (ACL/PCL), unicompartmental or TOTAL KNEE ARTHROPLASTY (primary or revision), tibial-plateau ORIF, synovectomy, etc.  
 • Key test: Is the primary surgical work INSIDE the knee joint capsule? If yes, choose 01400.

01402 – Anesthesia for procedures on the SHAFTS of the TIBIA and/or FIBULA (lower leg)  
 • Examples: IM nail or plate fixation of tibial/fibular fractures, osteotomies of the lower leg, removal of tibial/fibular hardware.  
 • EXCLUDES knee-joint work. A total knee replacement is NOT coded 01402, even though the tibial component is addressed—because the operative field is the knee joint.

01404 – Anesthesia for procedures on the ANKLE or FOOT (other than total ankle arthroplasty)  
 • Examples: calcaneal ORIF, ankle fusion, Lisfranc repair, bunionectomy.

01406 – Anesthesia for TOTAL ANKLE REPLACEMENT (ankle arthroplasty)  
 • Use instead of 01404 when a prosthetic ankle joint is implanted or revised.

Common Pitfall – 01400 vs. 01402  
Coders often mis-assign 01402 to knee replacements after seeing “tibia/fibula” in the descriptor. Remember:  
 • Total knee arthroplasty = knee-joint surgery ➔ 01400.  
 • Tibial/fibular shaft surgery (below the joint) ➔ 01402.

Quick Checklist for Knee Replacement Cases  
1. Operative note says “total knee arthroplasty/replacement” or “knee prosthesis revision.”  
2. Incision and instrumentation are confined to the knee joint.  
3. No extensive work on tibial/fibular shafts beyond the joint capsule.  
→ Code 01400.

Real-world Examples  
• Primary TKA with cemented components – 01400  
• Revision TKA with femoral/tibial stems – 01400  
• Tibial shaft intramedullary nail – 01402  
• Ankle fusion – 01404  
• Total ankle arthroplasty – 01406

Documentation Tip  
When in doubt, locate the primary anatomic site of the surgeon’s work. If the note states “joint capsule opened” or “femoral/tibial components placed inside the knee,” 01400 is the correct anesthesia code.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Knee and Popliteal Area Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing an open or arthroscopic procedure, including disarticulation, at the knee joint.
CPT.explanation: Code 01400 is appropriate for anesthesia during knee joint procedures. Code 01402 is more specific to tibia and fibula procedures, 01404 to foot and ankle procedures, and 01406 to total ankle replacement surgeries.

Code 01400 is appropriate for anesthesia during knee joint procedures. Code 01402 is more specific to tibia and fibula procedures, 01404 to foot and ankle procedures, and 01406 to total ankle replacement surgeries.

CPT.description: Fine Needle Aspiration Biopsy Procedures Summary: Under ultrasound guidance, the provider performs a fine needle aspiration (FNA), a diagnostic procedure that involves collecting a specimen from tissue, a cyst, or mass using a specialized needle and syringe. Report this code for the first lesion biopsied.

Biopsy Procedures on the Skin Summary: The provider biopsies a skin lesion using a punch technique with a sharp hollow instrument; punch biopsies are commonly performed for deeper circular skin lesions.
CPT.explanation: 11104 is the CPT code for punch biopsy of skin (including simple closure), when the diameter of the lesion is 0.5 cm or less.
11100 is the CPT code for biopsy of skin, subcutaneous tissue and/or mucous membrane (including simple closure), unless otherwise listed; single lesion.

CPT.description: Introduction and Removal Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider places a catheter through the skin of the abdominal wall, extremity, or neck to drain a fluid collection using imaging guidance.

Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of the entire thyroid or most of the thyroid, including the isthmus. The provider also performs limited lymph node dissection of the neck.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60240, pertains to a total thyroidectomy. While 60212 is for a thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60252 represents a thyroidectomy for malignancy with radical neck dissection. The scenario describes a total thyroidectomy without neck dissection, making 60240 the right choice.

CPT 99201  (Problem-Focused Office/Outpatient Visit – NEW Patient)  
STATUS: Deleted 1-1-2021. If you are coding with the 2021-present E/M rules, select 99202 (or time-based code) instead. If you are working under pre-2021 guidelines (some legacy payers, older test questions), the information below applies.

1. Patient Status – the FIRST gate
   • New Patient = has not received professional services from the physician/qualified health-care professional (or another of the same specialty/subspecialty in the same group) within the past 3 years.  
   • If the visit is for a new patient, you MUST choose from 99201-99205; you may NEVER report 99211-99215 (established patient series), no matter how “routine” or “brief” the encounter is.  
   → Most exam mistakes come from overlooking this rule.

2. Key Components required (pre-2021 rules)
   • Problem-focused history (brief HPI, no ROS or PFSH required).  
   • Problem-focused examination (limited to the affected body area/organ system).  
   • Straightforward medical decision making.  
   All three elements must be met or exceeded.

3. Time Threshold (pre-2021)
   • Typical face-to-face time: 10 min.

4. 2021-PRESENT rules (when 99201 is not reportable)
   • The lowest level new-patient E/M is 99202.  
   • Select 99202 when MDM is Straightforward OR when total physician/APP time is 15-29 min.

5. Quick “Which Code?” Decision Grid
   NEW pt + problem-focused/intake only → 99201 (legacy) or 99202 (current)  
   ESTABLISHED pt + problem-focused/intake only → 99212  
   Remember: Patient status overrides everything else.

6. Common Confusion – 99201 vs. 99212
   • 99201 = NEW patient; 99212 = ESTABLISHED patient.  
   • Both may involve a problem-focused history/exam, but they are not interchangeable because the patient status is different.  
   • Routine/wellness visits do NOT automatically make the patient “established.”

7. Practical Example
   Scenario: Jake is seen in your clinic for the first time. The provider documents a brief HPI (“feels well”), no ROS, no PFSH, performs a limited exam, makes no new diagnoses, and gives general health advice.  
   • Pre-2021 code: 99201.  
   • 2021+ code: 99202 (straightforward MDM or 15-29 min).

8. Payer Alert
   • Medicare and most commercial plans have removed 99201 from fee schedules. Attempting to bill it will result in denial; code 99202 where appropriate.  
   • Always verify your payer’s adoption year for E/M guidelines.

Mnemonic to avoid mix-ups  
N.E.W. = New Encounter → Use 9920X series  
E.S.T. = Established → Use 9921X series  

Summary: Use 99201 only for a NEW patient encounter meeting minimal/problem-focused criteria under pre-2021 rules. Never use 99212 for a new patient. Under current guidelines, default to 99202 for the lowest-level new-patient visit.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider sees a new patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a low level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 30 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99202 is used for an expanded problem-focused history and examination for new patients in an office or outpatient setting. 99201 is for a problem-focused history, 99203 is for a detailed history, and 99204 is for a comprehensive history.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider sees a new patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a moderate level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 45 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99202 is used for an expanded problem-focused history and examination for new patients in an office or outpatient setting. 99201 is for a problem-focused history, 99203 is for a detailed history, and 99204 is for a comprehensive history.

CPT.description: Removal of Skin Tags Procedures Summary: The provider removes skin tags in any area of the body, up to and including 15 lesions.
CPT.explanation: 11200 is the CPT code for removal of skin tags, multiple fibrocutaneous tags, any area; up to and including 15 lesions.

CPT.description: Other Procedures on the Nose Summary: The provider uses a simple or limited approach to stop a nosebleed caused by a vessel in the front area of the nose.
CPT.explanation: 30901 is the CPT code for control nasal hemorrhage, anterior, simple (e.g., epistaxis, cautery, packing) any method.

CPT.description: Intracardiac Electrophysiological Procedures/Studies Summary: The provider inserts and repositions multiple electrode catheters in the right atrium, His bundle region, and right ventricle to evaluate abnormal heart rhythm disturbances. This code represents both the technical and professional components of the service.

Intracardiac Electrophysiological Procedures/Studies Summary: The provider performs a comprehensive electrophysiologic study (EPS) by inserting multiple electrode–tipped catheters into the high right atrium, His bundle region, and right ventricle. The provider performs right atrial pacing and recording, His bundle recording, and right ventricular pacing and recording and induces or attempts to induce an arrhythmia.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 93620 represents a comprehensive electrophysiologic evaluation. The other codes refer to different types or parts of electrophysiology studies and aren't as comprehensive as 93620.

CPT.description: Intracardiac Electrophysiological Procedures/Studies Summary: In this add–on procedure, after initial induction of arrhythmia with pacing and recording of the right side of the heart and bundle of His, the provider inserts an additional catheter threaded through a venous sheath and moves it under fluoroscopic guidance through the coronary sinus for left atrial pacing and recording.

Intracardiac Electrophysiological Procedures/Studies Summary: In this add–on procedure, after initial induction of arrhythmia with pacing and recording of the right side of the heart and bundle of His, the provider inserts an additional catheter threaded through a venous sheath and moves it under fluoroscopic guidance for left ventricular pacing and recording.

CPT.explanation: 20002 is the CPT code for incision and drainage of abscess of skin, subcutaneous or accessory structures; arm or leg.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider sees a new patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves straightforward medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 15 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
99202 – Office or Other Outpatient Visit, NEW Patient  
(Pre-2021 “3-key component” rules; see note on current rules below)

WHEN TO USE  
• History: Expanded problem-focused  
  – Chief Complaint (CC)  
  – Brief HPI (1-3 elements or status of 1-3 chronic problems)  
  – Problem-pertinent ROS (review of ONE body system related to the CC)  
  – PFSH not required  
• Exam: Expanded problem-focused (limited exam of affected body area(s) + related organ system)  
• Medical Decision Making (MDM): Straightforward

HOW IT DIFFERS FROM THE OTHER NEW-PATIENT LEVELS (pre-2021)  
99201 – Problem-focused history/exam, NO ROS. If even a single ROS element is documented, the service automatically meets 99202. (Deleted 1-1-2021.)  
99203 – Detailed history/exam: CC + extended HPI (4+ elements) + ROS of 2-9 systems + 1 pertinent PFSH.  
99204 – Comprehensive history/exam: CC + extended HPI + complete ROS (10+) + complete PFSH (all 3 areas).

COMMON CODING PITFALL  
“Brief history” is often assumed to be 99201, but the presence of ANY ROS—no matter how short—elevates the visit to 99202. For example, a physician who documents “Patient with flu-like symptoms; denies chest pain or SOB” has obtained a respiratory ROS and is therefore at 99202 at minimum.

REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES  
✓ Patient with sore throat; HPI covers onset/duration/severity, and physician asks about fever/ear pain (ENT ROS). → 99202  
✗ Same patient, HPI only (“2-day sore throat”) with no ROS. → 99201 (before 2021)  
✓ New patient with cough; HPI plus ROS of respiratory system; limited lung exam; straightforward MDM. → 99202

CURRENT (2021+) GUIDELINES WARNING  
CPT 99201 was deleted, and history/exam are no longer “counted” to select the code. Under the 2021+ rules, 99202 is chosen by:  
• MDM = Straightforward, OR  
• Total time 15–29 min (including prep, counseling, documentation).  
Always verify which E/M guideline year your payer is using.

CPT.description: Introduction Procedures on the Bladder Summary: Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG). This is a technique which is performed to detect reflux by watching a person's urethra and urinary bladder during his or her micturition.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: The lab analyst performs the technical lab test to analyze the concentration of a particular gamma globulin in the specimen. The analyst may test for immunoglobulin A, immunoglobulin D, immunoglobulin G, or immunoglobulin M. Specimens include serum, plasma, cerebrospinal fluid, or other bodily fluids.
CPT.explanation: Code 82784 is for the immunoglobulin test. The other codes represent different types of immunoglobulin tests or variations, but 82784 is the general code for such a test.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: The lab analyst performs the technical lab test to analyze the quantity of immunoglobulin E in the specimen.
Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an incision in the tongue and excises the lesion from the tongue.
CPT.explanation: 41110 pertains to excision of lesion of oral mucosa without closure.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts a flexible cannula in the maxillary sinus through a cut in the antrum or through a natural opening to wash out the contents of the maxillary sinus.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: Partial surgical anterior ethmoidectomy involves the removal of the uncinate process (infundibulotomy), opening of the bulla, and partial removal of the anterior ethmoid cells.
Repair Procedures on the Nose Summary: Septoplasty is most often performed for a deviated septum which can be either C–shaped, S–shaped, or a cartilaginous deviation.
CPT.explanation: 30520 is the CPT code for septoplasty or submucous resection, with or without cartilage scoring, contouring or replacement with graft.
